verses.text: Then Jesus left that place and went to the region of Judea and beyond the Jordan, and crowds gathered to Him again. As He was accustomed, He began to teach them once more.
verses.comment: Here we see Jesus continuing His ministry, teaching large crowds—a pattern that highlights His role as Teacher and Shepherd. Reference to Judea and crossing the Jordan recalls Israel’s ancient boundaries (Josh. 3:14-17).

verses.text: Some Pharisees came and, to test Him, asked, 'Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?'
verses.comment: The Pharisees’ question refers to Mosaic law (Deut. 24:1) and highlights their intent to challenge Jesus’ authority. This sets the stage for Jesus to clarify God’s original purpose for marriage.

verses.text: He answered them, 'What did Moses command you?'
verses.comment: Jesus directs them to Scripture, showing His respect for divine revelation and inviting them to consider the true meaning of the law.

verses.text: They said, 'Moses allowed a man to write a certificate of divorce and send her away.'
verses.comment: The Pharisees reference the letter of the law, but miss the heart behind God’s intent concerning marriage.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Because of your hardness of heart, he wrote this commandment for you.'
verses.comment: Jesus reveals that the Mosaic concession was not the ideal, but a temporary measure. He urges a return to God’s original plan, emphasizing transformation of the heart.

verses.text: 'But from the beginning of creation, He made them male and female.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the creation account (Gen. 1:27), teaching that marriage reflects a divinely instituted order. He upholds both the literal and spiritual union.

verses.text: 'For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife,'
verses.comment: By citing Genesis, Jesus points to the foundational nature of marriage, a covenant bond prefiguring the unity between Christ and the Church (Eph. 5:31-32).

verses.text: 'and the two shall become one flesh.' So they are no longer two, but one flesh.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the indissoluble nature of marriage. The spiritual reality of ‘one flesh’ alludes to Christ’s union with believers—an intimate and enduring bond.

verses.text: 'Therefore what God has joined together, let no one separate.'
verses.comment: Marriage is elevated as a divine institution. Jesus establishes a high standard for matrimonial unity, which points toward faithfulness like that of Christ for His people.

verses.text: When they were back in the house, the disciples questioned Him again about this matter.
verses.comment: The disciples seek further clarification, showing the importance of authoritative teaching within the community of believers.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery against her.'
verses.comment: Jesus definitively condemns divorce and remarriage, upholding the sanctity of the marital covenant. This pursuit of holiness suggests the significance of sacramental grace (see Heb. 13:4).

verses.text: And if she divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery.
verses.comment: Jesus treats both men and women equally in His statement, highlighting the universal call to fidelity and purity.

verses.text: People were bringing little children to Him so that He might touch them, but the disciples rebuked those who brought them.
verses.comment: Children were considered insignificant in ancient society; Jesus reverses expectations, demonstrating the kingdom’s openness to the humble and lowly.

verses.text: When Jesus saw this, He was indignant and said to them, 'Let the children come to Me; do not hinder them, for the kingdom of God belongs to such as these.'
verses.comment: Christ affirms the dignity of children, and His actions prefigure sacramental blessing, grace imparted to those unable to understand or ask for themselves.

verses.text: Truly I tell you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a little child will never enter it.
verses.comment: Entrance into the kingdom requires humility and trust, not self-reliance. Spiritual childhood is commended, reminiscent of the ‘poverty of spirit’ (Matt. 5:3).

verses.text: And He took them in His arms and blessed them, laying His hands on them.
verses.comment: Jesus’ gesture echoes the Old Testament patriarchal blessing (Gen. 48:14). The laying on of hands anticipates the transmission of grace through physical means.

verses.text: As He was setting out on His way, a man ran up and knelt before Him and asked, 'Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?'
verses.comment: Addressing Jesus as ‘Good Teacher’ acknowledges special authority. The man’s question expresses a longing for salvation, a central theme in Christ’s mission.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Why do you call Me good? No one is good except God alone.'
verses.comment: Jesus subtly points to His divinity, prompting the seeker to reflect on His true identity. Only God is perfectly good, an attribute ascribed to Jesus throughout the Gospels.

verses.text: 'You know the commandments: Do not murder, Do not commit adultery, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Do not defraud, Honor your father and mother.'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes the Ten Commandments, underscoring their enduring relevance. The command not to defraud may reference fair dealings, expanding application to everyday life.

verses.text: He replied, 'Teacher, all these I have kept since my youth.'
verses.comment: The man’s claim reveals a sincere pursuit of righteousness, yet Jesus will soon invite him to a deeper, more radical discipleship.

verses.text: Jesus looked at him, loved him, and said, 'One thing you lack: go, sell all you own and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ invitation points to the radical call of discipleship and detachment from worldly possessions. His love reveals the personal nature of divine demands.

verses.text: At this, the man’s face fell. He went away sorrowful, for he had many possessions.
verses.comment: Attachment to wealth hinders spiritual progress. This scene illustrates the challenge of placing God above material concerns—a theme echoed in monastic traditions.

verses.text: Jesus looked around and said to His disciples, 'How hard it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!'
verses.comment: Worldly wealth creates spiritual obstacles, reminding us that fulfillment comes from God alone.

verses.text: The disciples were amazed at His words. But Jesus said again, 'Children, how hard it is to enter the kingdom of God!'
verses.comment: Christ calls the disciples ‘children,’ highlighting their need to rely on God’s grace rather than human effort.

verses.text: 'It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: An image of impossibility, underscoring total dependence on God for salvation, since human works alone cannot suffice.

verses.text: They were exceedingly astonished, and said among themselves, 'Then who can be saved?'
verses.comment: The disciples’ amazement reveals human inability to achieve salvation apart from divine help.

verses.text: Jesus looked at them and said, 'With man it is impossible, but not with God. For all things are possible with God.'
verses.comment: Salvation is ultimately the work of God’s grace; faith and trust in divine agency are essential for entering the kingdom.

verses.text: Peter began to say to Him, 'See, we have left everything and followed You.'
verses.comment: Peter voices the disciple’s radical commitment, echoing themes of renunciation found in the spiritual tradition of the saints.

verses.text: Jesus replied, 'Truly I tell you, there is no one who has left house or brothers or sisters or mother or father or children or fields, for My sake and for the gospel,
verses.comment: Jesus commends total self-giving for the sake of the gospel, which points to a deep vocation lived out in community and family renunciation for a higher good.

verses.text: 'who will not receive a hundredfold now in this time—houses, brothers, sisters, mothers, children, and fields, along with persecutions—and in the age to come, eternal life.'
verses.comment: The promise blends present blessings with trials. Jesus affirms the principle of reward for sacrifice, both in this life and in eternity, reflecting the communion of saints.

verses.text: 'But many who are first will be last, and the last first.'
verses.comment: God’s kingdom overturns worldly values; humility and self-sacrifice are exalted, reminding us that divine reward is not governed by human standards.

verses.text: They were on the way, going up to Jerusalem, and Jesus was walking ahead of them. The disciples were amazed, and those who followed were afraid. Taking the twelve aside again, He began to tell them what would happen to Him:
verses.comment: Jesus’ journey to Jerusalem emphasizes His resolute mission. His prophecy of suffering demonstrates His foreknowledge and acceptance, highlighting His divine identity.

verses.text: 'See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be delivered to the chief priests and the scribes, and they will condemn Him to death and deliver Him to the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies His betrayal and suffering, fulfilling ancient prophecy (Isaiah 53). ‘Son of Man’ echoes Daniel 7:13-14—a title of both humanity and divinity.

verses.text: 'They will mock Him, spit on Him, flog Him, and kill Him. And after three days He will rise.'
verses.comment: Jesus foretells His Passion and Resurrection—central mysteries of faith. Rising on the third day fulfills scriptural patterns of redemption.

verses.text: Then James and John, the sons of Zebedee, approached Him and said, 'Teacher, we want You to do for us whatever we ask.'
verses.comment: The request reveals human ambition and misunderstanding of true greatness in Christ’s kingdom.

verses.text: He said to them, 'What do you want Me to do for you?'
verses.comment: Jesus engages their request, inviting honest dialogue—a hallmark of His relational approach.

verses.text: They said to Him, 'Grant us to sit, one at Your right hand and one at Your left, in Your glory.'
verses.comment: They seek privileged positions, echoing Old Testament images of royal glory (Psalm 110:1). True glory, as Jesus will explain, comes through service and suffering.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'You do not know what you are asking. Can you drink the cup that I drink, or be baptized with the baptism I am baptized with?'
verses.comment: The ‘cup’ and ‘baptism’ symbolize suffering and death. Sharing in Christ’s glory requires sharing in His Passion—a spiritual reality reflected in life-long commitment.

verses.text: They replied, 'We can.' And Jesus said to them, 'You will drink the cup that I drink, and be baptized with the baptism I am baptized with,'
verses.comment: The apostles would share in suffering for Christ, exemplifying the call to follow Jesus unto self-sacrifice.

verses.text: 'but to sit at My right or left is not Mine to grant, but it is for those for whom it has been prepared.'
verses.comment: He emphasizes the Father’s divine providence in appointing honors; humility, rather than self-advancement, is encouraged.

verses.text: When the ten heard this, they became angry at James and John.
verses.comment: Jealousy among the apostles highlights the common temptation to seek status, even within the community of believers.

verses.text: Jesus called them together and said, 'You know that those who are recognized as rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them.'
verses.comment: Worldly authority is contrasted with service, setting up the new understanding of leadership in the kingdom.

verses.text: But it shall not be so among you. Rather, whoever would be great among you must be your servant,
verses.comment: True greatness is found in humble service, reflecting the life of Christ, who serves all.

verses.text: and whoever would be first among you must be slave of all.
verses.comment: Christian leadership is redefined as self-giving, a call to serve in the pattern of the Master.

verses.text: For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve and to give His life as a ransom for many.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims divine prerogative to offer His life as a ransom—a central act of salvation. The ‘ransom’ evokes fulfillment of messianic prophecy (Isaiah 53:12).

verses.text: They came to Jericho. As He was leaving Jericho with His disciples and a large crowd, Bartimaeus, a blind beggar, son of Timaeus, was sitting by the roadside.
verses.comment: Jericho was the place of Israel’s first victory in the land (Josh. 6). Bartimaeus’ blindness points to spiritual need, anticipating Christ’s healing work.

verses.text: When he heard that it was Jesus of Nazareth, he began to cry out, 'Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: Bartimaeus’ address recognizes Jesus as the Messiah, heir to David’s throne—asserting both His humanity and divinity.

verses.text: Many rebuked him, telling him to be quiet, but he cried out even more, 'Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: Persistence in prayer is encouraged; Bartimaeus models faith that refuses to be silenced or discouraged.

verses.text: Jesus stopped and said, 'Call him.' So they called the blind man, saying to him, 'Take heart; rise, He is calling you.'
verses.comment: Jesus responds to faith. The community encourages engagement with Christ, foreshadowing the mediating role of the Church and its saints.

verses.text: Throwing off his cloak, he jumped up and came to Jesus.
verses.comment: Bartimaeus leaves behind his possessions to respond to Jesus—a symbol of radical trust and surrender.

verses.text: Jesus asked him, 'What do you want Me to do for you?' And the blind man said to Him, 'Rabbi, let me recover my sight.'
verses.comment: Personal encounter with Jesus allows for honest prayer. Calling Him ‘Rabbi’ shows recognition of unique authority.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Go; your faith has made you well.' Immediately he regained his sight and followed Him on the way.
verses.comment: Healing occurs through faith, a testimony to Christ’s divine power. Bartimaeus’ following of Jesus signifies discipleship, joining the community of faith.
